headline: Ethereum Wakes Up as Bitcoin Holds Ground

sections.the_lead:
While Asia slept, Ethereum remembered it was supposed to be interesting. A 5.9% overnight surge—the strongest single-session move in three weeks—pulled the broader market higher, with Bitcoin consolidating above $92,000 on modest volume. The move originated in European hours, accelerated through the New York close, and now lands on Hong Kong and Singapore desks as a fait accompli rather than an opportunity.

The setup entering Asian hours is one of cautious momentum. Total market capitalisation crossed $3.25 trillion, but the advance lacks the volume signature of genuine institutional conviction. Japanese markets return from a quiet Monday with MUFG and Nomura both reportedly expanding their digital asset custody discussions—a slow-burn story that matters more than today's price action. Korean retail, typically the marginal buyer in moves like this, showed restrained participation overnight according to Upbit flow data.

Today hinges on whether Hong Kong's institutional desks treat this as a breakout to chase or a gap to fade. The answer will tell us whether this is the start of rotation or merely a short squeeze wearing a suit.
sections.the_lead_title: ETH Leads a Quiet Overnight Rally
sections.the_angle: Everyone is celebrating Ethereum's outperformance as validation of the asset. They are missing the more important signal: this move happened on a Sunday night into a Monday morning, when institutional order flow is at its weekly nadir. What looks like strength is actually a liquidity gap being exploited. The real test comes when Tokyo and Hong Kong institutional desks decide whether to add to positions or take the gift. Overnight moves that stick tell you about conviction. Overnight moves that fade tell you about positioning.
sections.the_driver:
• Ethereum's 5.9% advance outpaced Bitcoin by more than three-to-one, compressing the ETH/BTC ratio's recent decline and triggering a cascade of altcoin sympathy bids—Solana's 3.2% gain suggests the move is being read as risk-on rotation rather than ETH-specific news.

• Bitcoin dominance slipped to 56.9% from 57.4% over 24 hours, the sharpest single-day compression since early November, indicating capital is finally willing to venture beyond the flagship asset after weeks of concentration.

• Trading volume at $143 billion sits 12% below the 30-day average despite the price appreciation, a divergence that historically precedes either continuation on fresh capital or swift mean reversion—the next 48 hours will clarify which.

• Chinese state media ran unusually neutral coverage of Hong Kong's digital asset framework over the weekend, a subtle shift from the dismissive tone of recent months that institutional desks in the region are quietly noting.
sections.the_signal:
• ETH/BTC at 0.0358 — still near cycle lows despite the overnight move, suggesting this rally needs follow-through to signal genuine rotation rather than a dead cat bounce.

• 24-hour liquidations at $89 million (68% shorts) — meaningful but not extreme, indicating the move caught bears off-guard without triggering the cascade that would suggest exhaustion.

• Bitcoin spot ETF premium at 0.12% — institutional vehicles trading nearly flat to NAV suggests the overnight move was futures-led, not spot-driven, which typically means less staying power.
sections.the_takeaway: The most informative price moves happen when the people who would normally sell are asleep—what matters now is whether they wake up as buyers or sellers.

image_keywords: Hong Kong skyline, Victoria Harbour, soft morning light, clear sky
